name: Morning Light Exposure
description: Morning light (10-30 min, ≥1,000 lux, within 60 min of waking) advances sleep phase by 0.5-2.7 hours and improves sleep efficiency by 10-15% within 1-2 weeks. Amplifies cortisol awakening response by >50%, enhancing alertness and mood.
benefits: Advances sleep phase, improves sleep efficiency, enhances alertness and mood.
constraints: Avoid direct sun staring. Bipolar disorder: consult physician. Retinal disorders: consult ophthalmologist.
citations: Wright, K.P., et al. (2013). Entrainment of the human circadian clock to the natural light-dark cycle. Current Biology.
Terman, M., et al. (2001). Circadian time of morning light administration and therapeutic response in winter depression. Archives of General Psychiatry.
Leproult, R., et al. (2001). Transition from dim to bright light in the morning induces an immediate elevation of cortisol levels. JCEM.
Crowley, S.J., & Eastman, C.I. (2015). Phase advancing human circadian rhythms with morning bright light. Sleep Medicine Reviews.
summary: Get 10-30 minutes of outdoor light within 1 hour of waking to reset circadian rhythm and boost energy.

name: Evening Light Management
description: Evening light management (dim lights <50 lux, blue light minimization 2-3 hours pre-sleep) preserves melatonin secretion and optimizes sleep onset. Bright evening light (>500 lux) delays circadian phase by 1-3 hours and suppresses melatonin by 55-71%.
benefits: Preserves melatonin, optimizes sleep onset, stabilizes circadian phase.
constraints: Bright overhead lights suppress melatonin even with blue blockers. Night shift workers require inverted protocol.
citations: Chang, A.M., et al. (2015). Evening use of light-emitting eReaders negatively affects sleep. PNAS.
Gooley, J.J., et al. (2011). Exposure to room light before bedtime suppresses melatonin onset. JCEM.
Vethe, D., et al. (2021). The evening light environment in hospitals... Sleep.
summary: Dim lights and avoid screens 2-3 hours before bed to preserve melatonin.

name: Sleep Optimization
description: Evidence-based sleep optimization requires temperature control (60-67°F), pre-sleep warm baths 90 min before bedtime, meal cutoffs 3 hours prior, alcohol avoidance 4+ hours before bed, and bedtime consistency ±30 min.
benefits: Improves sleep onset, duration, and efficiency. Enhances recovery.
constraints: Untreated sleep disorders (apnea) may limit effectiveness. Shift workers require inverted protocol.
citations: Raj, A., et al. (2020). Higher bedroom temperature associated with poorer sleep. Sleep.
Haghayegh, S., et al. (2019). Before-bedtime passive body heating... Sleep Medicine Reviews.
Gardiner, C., et al. (2024). The effect of alcohol on subsequent sleep. Sleep Medicine Reviews.
Chaput, J.P., et al. (2020). Sleep timing, sleep consistency, and health. Sleep Medicine Reviews.
summary: Optimize sleep environment (cool room) and habits (consistency, warm bath) for deep recovery.

name: Hydration & Electrolytes
description: Even mild dehydration (1-2% body mass) impairs mood and cognition. Morning hydration (16-32 oz + electrolytes within 30 min of waking) optimizes cortisol awakening response and cognitive readiness.
benefits: Improves mood, concentration, and executive function. Restores fluid balance.
constraints: Kidney disease or hypertension: consult physician regarding sodium/potassium intake.
citations: Armstrong, L.E., et al. (2012). Mild dehydration affects mood in healthy young women. The Journal of Nutrition.
Masento, N.A., et al. (2014). Effects of hydration status on cognitive performance and mood. British Journal of Nutrition.
Wittbrodt, M.T., & Millard-Stafford, M. (2018). Autonomic adaptations mediate the effect of hydration on brain functioning. Physiology & Behavior.
summary: Drink 16-32oz water with electrolytes immediately upon waking.

name: Caffeine Timing & Cutoff
description: Caffeine cutoff 8-10 hours before bedtime preserves sleep onset and quality. Delaying first caffeine 90-120 min post-wake may reduce afternoon crashes.
benefits: Preserves deep sleep and sleep onset. Reduces afternoon energy crashes.
constraints: Anxiety disorders: limit intake. Pregnancy: limit to 200mg/day.
citations: Drake, C., et al. (2013). Caffeine effects on sleep taken 0, 3, or 6 hours before going to bed. JCSM.
Gardiner, C.L., et al. (2025). Dose and timing effects of caffeine on subsequent sleep. Sleep.
Burke, T.M., et al. (2015). Effects of caffeine on the human circadian clock. Science Translational Medicine.
summary: Stop caffeine 8-10 hours before bed; optionally delay morning intake 90 minutes.

name: Morning Movement
description: Light-to-moderate aerobic exercise (Zone 2) within 30-90 min of waking enhances cortisol awakening response by 50-75% and increases alertness.
benefits: Amplifies cortisol awakening response, boosts alertness and mood.
constraints: Respect physical injuries. Adjust for chronotype (evening types may need later window).
citations: Drogos, L.L., et al. (2019). Aerobic exercise increases cortisol awakening response. Eur J Appl Physiol.
Shen, B., et al. (2025). Differential benefits of 12-week morning vs. evening exercise. Scientific Reports.
summary: 10-30 minutes of moderate movement (Zone 2) within 90 mins of waking.

name: Walking Breaks & Micro-Movement
description: 2-5 min light walking every 20-30 min during sedentary work reduces postprandial glucose by 17-58% and preserves cerebral blood flow.
benefits: Reduces glucose spikes, maintains focus, prevents cerebral blood flow decline.
constraints: Workplace constraints may require seated alternatives.
citations: Dunstan, D.W., et al. (2012). Breaking up prolonged sitting reduces postprandial glucose. Diabetes Care.
Diaz, K.M., et al. (2023). Interrupting sitting time with brief walking activity. MSSE.
Carter, S.E., et al. (2018). Regular walking breaks prevent decline in cerebral blood flow. J Appl Physiol.
summary: Take a 2-5 minute walk every 30 minutes of sitting.

name: Nutrition for Cognitive Stability
description: Protein-driven neurotransmitter synthesis, low-glycemic carbs, and circadian meal timing (finish 3h before sleep) support cognitive stability.
benefits: Sustained energy/focus, improved sleep quality, metabolic health.
constraints: Dietary restrictions (medical/ethical) require adaptation. Eating disorders: avoid rigid tracking.
citations: Adams, M.S., et al. (2025). Effects of dietary proteins on cognitive performance. Nutrition Research Reviews.
Li, Y., et al. (2025). Association of dietary protein intake... Frontiers in Nutrition.
Gonçalves, N.G., et al. (2023). Association between consumption of ultraprocessed foods and cognitive decline. JAMA Neurol.
summary: Prioritize protein, low-GI foods, and finish eating 3 hours before bed.

name: Fitness for Focus
description: Aerobic exercise (Zone 2) and resistance training upregulate BDNF, improving executive function and memory.
benefits: Increases BDNF, improves executive function and memory, reverses hippocampal atrophy.
constraints: Medical clearance required for >40 sedentary/high-risk. Respect recovery needs (HRV).
citations: Erickson, K.I., et al. (2011). Exercise training increases size of hippocampus. PNAS.
Sartori, G.P., et al. (2022). Effects of different physical activities on BDNF. Frontiers in Neuroscience.
Singh, B., et al. (2025). Effectiveness of exercise for improving cognition. BJSM.
summary: Regular aerobic and resistance training to boost brain plasticity and focus.

name: NSDR & Meditation
description: NSDR (Non-Sleep Deep Rest) and meditation induce theta brainwaves, increase dopamine (+65% with Yoga Nidra), and accelerate recovery.
benefits: Accelerates recovery, increases dopamine, improves sleep quality and HRV.
constraints: Active psychosis/severe trauma: modify practice type.
citations: Meta-analysis of 163 meditation studies (dose-response).
Yoga Nidra dopamine release studies (PET imaging).
summary: 10-20 mins of Yoga Nidra or meditation to recover energy and focus.

name: Breathwork & HRV Regulation
description: Controlled breathing (cyclic sighing, box breathing) modulates autonomic balance, reducing anxiety by 22% and increasing HRV.
benefits: Rapid anxiety reduction, increased HRV, stress resilience.
constraints: Panic disorder: avoid breath holding. Pregnancy: avoid hyperventilation.
citations: Balban et al. (2023). Brief structured respiration practices enhance mood and reduce physiological arousal. Cell Reports Medicine.
summary: Use Cyclic Sighing (5 min) for anxiety or Box Breathing for focus.

name: Cold Exposure
description: 11 mins/week of cold exposure increases norepinephrine (+530%) and dopamine (+250%), enhancing mood and resilience.
benefits: Increases alertness/dopamine, reduces inflammation, builds stress resilience.
constraints: Cardiovascular disease: consult physician. Raynaud's: avoid. Pregnancy: avoid.
citations: Søberg et al. (2021). Altered brown fat thermoregulation... Cell Metabolism.
Kox et al. (2014). Voluntary activation of the sympathetic nervous system... PNAS.
summary: 11 minutes total weekly cold exposure (shower/plunge) for resilience and dopamine.

name: Foundational Supplement Stack
description: Addresses common deficiencies (Vitamin D, Omega-3, Magnesium) to support sleep, mood, and cognition.
benefits: Fills nutrient gaps, supports sleep (Magnesium), mood (Vit D/Omega-3), and cognition.
constraints: Medical contraindications apply (e.g., kidney disease, blood thinners). Consult physician.
citations: Anglin et al. (2013). Vitamin D and depression meta-analysis.
Skulas-Ray et al. (2019). Omega-3 fatty acids... Circulation.
Abbasi et al. (2012). Effect of magnesium on insomnia... J Res Med Sci.
summary: Vitamin D, Omega-3, and Magnesium to cover biological bases.

name: Dopamine Optimization
description: Managing dopamine baseline via reward delay, cold exposure, and avoiding overstimulation (social media) prevents anhedonia.
benefits: Restores motivation, prevents burnout/anhedonia, improves focus.
constraints: Clinical depression/ADHD: adjust strategy with professional support.
citations: PET imaging studies on D2/D3 receptor density and recovery.
summary: Manage cheap dopamine (screens) and use healthy tools (cold, sun) to sustain motivation.

name: Alcohol & Sleep Quality
description: Alcohol within 3-4 hours of bed suppresses REM sleep and reduces HRV. A strict cutoff minimizes disruption.
benefits: Preserves REM sleep, HRV, and recovery.
constraints: Alcohol Use Disorder: seek professional help. Do not combine with sleep meds.
citations: Meta-analysis (27 studies) on alcohol and sleep architecture.
summary: Stop alcohol 3-4 hours before bed to protect sleep quality.

name: Focus & Information Diet
description: Deep work blocks (90 min) and batched notifications reduce context switching and cognitive fatigue.
benefits: Increases productivity and sustained attention. Reduces decision fatigue.
citations: Shah et al. (2019). Organizational policies reduced notifications...
Skowronek et al. (2023). Smartphone separation and cognitive performance.
summary: Batch notifications and use deep work blocks to maximize cognitive output.

name: Cognitive Testing & Reflection
description: Weekly self-assessment (mood, reflection) increases self-awareness and adherence.
constraints: Avoid obsessive daily checking; stick to weekly.
citations: Meta-analysis of digital interventions on self-monitoring.
summary: Weekly review of mood and progress to optimize protocols.

name: Social Connection & Accountability
description: Peer accountability increases adherence by ~60% through social pressure and support.
benefits: Increases habit consistency, reduces isolation, improves mental health.
constraints: Avoid shame-based accountability. Match with compatible partners.
citations: Meta-analysis of 148 studies on social relationships and mortality.
Habit-based interventions with social support effect sizes.
summary: Use a buddy or team to boost consistency and motivation.
